text.headline: Alchemist
text.text:
Ancient Mesopotamians practiced distillation—that is, the purification of liquids—through boiling and condensation, yet Johannes Stradanus prominently included the art in his Nova Reperta series as if it were a “new discovery.” From its earliest days, distillation served many medical and chemical uses: one could purify water and medicine, create potent alcohol and perfume, or use the process for further research. Indeed, Stradanus’s Distillation print depicts it as a collaborative and experimental process—specifically, alchemy. Alchemists from the thirteenth century onwards were often seen as being consumed by the mystical pursuit of metallic transmutation. They sought the so-called Philosopher's Stone, which was said to turn lead into gold, but also promised medical and life-extending properties. Alchemy never achieved this arcane goal, but nonetheless helped develop other types of profitable knowledge, including the first method to produce porcelain in Europe.

Main image: Philips Galle after Johannes Stradanus, Distillatio (Invention of Distillation), from Nova Reperta (New Discoveries), c. 1588. Engraving, Newberry Library. See the original Newberry album here.

media.credit: Adam Lonicer, Distillation Tools, in Kreutterbuch (Herbal), 1546, Newberry Library.

text.headline: the tools of DISTILLATION and alchemy
text.text: Distillation and Alchemy required the same tools. Green glass retorts (bottles with elegantly extruded necks to aid condensation), pairs of copper alembic vessels connected by tubing, and gray leaden stands are some of the distinctive tools that sixteenth-century practitioners used to distill herbs and various animal, vegetable and mineral substances into alcohol and medicine. Stradanus's Distillation engraving shows assistants grinding and pressing herbs, and stoking furnaces. He even hints at the transparency of the flasks attached to the central still. These appeared in functional color in Adam Lonicer's popular 1546 do-it-yourself herbal. Offering plague cures rather than the mystical cure-alls of alchemy, the book was frequently reprinted into the seventeenth century.

media.credit: Gérard Edelinck, Portrait of Francesco I de' Medici, ca 1707. Engraving, Metropolitan Museum of Art.

text.headline: the nobility of alchemy
text.text: Many noblemen, like Grand Duke Francesco I de’ Medici, were obsessed with the potential commercial benefits of alchemy for mining and other speculative endeavors. His portrait, standing in the center, also appeared in Stradanus’s similar painting of an alchemical workshop for Francesco’s Palazzo Vecchio study. The Newberry's 1559 letter to his mother (Vault Case MS 5127), seen here, includes Francesco’s autograph signature.

media.credit: Sebastian Brant, Scholar, in Stultifera Navis (Ship of Fools), 1506, Newberry Library.

text.headline: The study of alchemy
text.text: Many philosophers and physicians pursued the elusive truths of alchemical experimentation above and beyond distillation. In fact, plenty had already been written about alchemy by the seventeenth century. Paracelsus (1493-1541), a prolific Swiss experimenter and writer, was partly responsible for developing the discipline that would become chemistry, but others like Isaac Newton (1643-1727) also contributed to the philosophical heft of the quest for the Philosopher’s Stone and other forms of alchemical mastery. Yet these efforts were not taken universally seriously. The scholar with his reading glasses and enormous book is shown with less authority here in the engraving than in Stradanus’s painting. He may be referencing Sebastian Brant’s parody of a scholar with oversized spectacles and under-developed intellect in the bestselling Ship of Fools.

media.credit: Pieter van der Borcht I, after Pieter Breugel I, Alchemist, from Apenspel (Ape Games), 1558-1608. Etching, Rijksmuseum.

text.headline: The perils of alchemy
text.text: As the sparsely-decked table in the painting within the Distillation engraving implies, most alchemists had little to show for their efforts. Numerous prints after designs by the likes of Pieter Breugel the Elder poked fun at the obsessions of these self-deluding stereotypes, for who among them had actually changed the elemental makeup of lead, or improved their longevity? Real progress might result in a now commonplace chemical formulae instead. Nova Reperta publisher Philips Galle envisioned the topsy-turvy alchemical household as populated by monkeys, but the clothes of the misguided adept, and of his wife, and children, remain tattered all the same.
